tips.title: The Weather Opener
tips.content: Starting with weather is a classic for a reason - it's universal and non-threatening. Try: 'Quite a day we're having!' instead of just 'Nice weather.'
tips.practice: Next time you're in an elevator or waiting in line, comment on the weather to someone nearby.

tips.title: The Observation Technique
tips.content: Notice something positive about your environment and share it. 'This coffee shop has such a cozy atmosphere' or 'That's an interesting book cover.'
tips.practice: Make three environmental observations today and share one with someone.

tips.title: The Genuine Compliment
tips.content: Compliment choices, not appearance. 'I love your backpack, where did you get it?' feels less personal than appearance-based compliments.
tips.practice: Give one choice-based compliment today (clothing, accessories, book choice, etc.)

tips.title: The Power Pose
tips.content: Before social situations, stand tall with hands on hips for 2 minutes. This 'power pose' actually increases confidence hormones.
tips.practice: Do a power pose before your next social interaction.

tips.title: Eye Contact Formula
tips.content: Try the 70% rule: maintain eye contact 70% of the time while speaking, 50% while listening. Look at the bridge of their nose if direct contact is hard.
tips.practice: Practice the 70% rule in your next conversation.

tips.title: Open vs Closed Posture
tips.content: Keep arms uncrossed, shoulders back, and body angled toward the person. This signals openness and interest.
tips.practice: Notice your posture in conversations today and adjust to be more open.

tips.title: The Echo Technique
tips.content: Repeat the last few words someone says as a question. 'You went to Paris?' This shows you're listening and prompts them to continue.
tips.practice: Use the echo technique three times in conversations today.

tips.title: Verbal Nods
tips.content: Use small sounds like 'mm-hmm,' 'oh,' and 'I see' to show engagement without interrupting. These encourage the speaker.
tips.practice: Count how many verbal nods you use in your next conversation.

tips.title: Summary Reflection
tips.content: Occasionally summarize what someone said: 'So you're saying that...' This confirms understanding and shows deep listening.
tips.practice: Try one summary reflection in a conversation today.

tips.title: The AND Technique
tips.content: Answer questions AND add information. Instead of just 'Yes, I like coffee,' try 'Yes, I love coffee! I just discovered cold brew.'
tips.practice: Answer three questions today using the AND technique.

tips.title: Open-Ended Questions
tips.content: Ask questions that can't be answered with yes/no. 'What brought you here?' instead of 'Do you come here often?'
tips.practice: Ask five open-ended questions in conversations today.

tips.title: The Story Prompt
tips.content: When someone mentions something, ask for the story: 'How did you get into that?' or 'What made you choose that?'
tips.practice: Ask for one story behind someone's interest or choice.

tips.title: The 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
tips.content: When anxious, notice: 5 things you see, 4 you can touch, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste. This grounds you in the present.
tips.practice: Practice 5-4-3-2-1 before entering a social situation.

tips.title: The Arrival Strategy
tips.content: Arrive early to events. It's easier to greet people one-by-one as they arrive than to enter a full room.
tips.practice: Arrive 10 minutes early to your next social event.

tips.title: The Helper Role
tips.content: Volunteer to help at events (taking coats, serving food). Having a role reduces anxiety and gives natural conversation starters.
tips.practice: Offer to help with one task at your next gathering.

tips.title: The Positive Close
tips.content: End conversations on a high note: 'It was really nice talking with you about X!' This leaves a positive impression.
tips.practice: Use a positive close to end three conversations today.

tips.title: The Future Reference
tips.content: Mention something future-oriented: 'I'll have to try that restaurant you mentioned!' This suggests ongoing connection.
tips.practice: Make one future reference when ending a conversation.

tips.title: The Honest Exit
tips.content: It's okay to say: 'I'm going to mingle a bit more' or 'I need to refresh my drink.' Honesty is better than awkward lingering.
tips.practice: Use one honest exit line today instead of making excuses.
